message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest intussusception, a condition where one part of the intestine slides into the next segment like a telescope. Air enema is the preferred diagnostic and therapeutic procedure for intussusception and is the next step in the management of the patient. Abdominal CT scan and radiograph can be used to diagnose intussusception but are not the first-line tests. Observation for 24 hours is not recommended given the presence of bloody stools.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest intussusception, which is a medical emergency. Air enema is the standard diagnostic and therapeutic procedure for intussusception in children. Abdominal CT scan and radiograph may have radiation exposure and are less commonly used for the diagnosis of intussusception. Observing for 24 hours is not appropriate as immediate medical intervention is needed for intussusception.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including severe stomach ache and bloody mucousy stools, indicate the possibility of intussusception, a condition in which one part of the intestine slides into the next, leading to blockage. Air enema is the preferred method for diagnosis and treatment in pediatric patients. Abdominal CT scan and radiograph may also be used, but air enema is preferred for initial management. Observation for 24 hours is not recommended as intussusception can lead to serious complications if left untreated.

We refer to Mayo Clinic's article on intussusception for help. The symptoms suggest intussusception, which is a medical emergency that requires prompt treatment. Air enema is the most common and effective method of diagnosis and treatment, which involves pushing air or liquid into the rectum to push the telescoped intestine back into place. Abdominal CT scan or radiograph may also be used to diagnose intussusception, but the air enema is the preferred method. Observation for 24 hours is not appropriate because intussusception can lead to intestinal obstruction and tissue damage if left untreated.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest intussusception, which is a medical emergency in children. Air enema is the preferred diagnostic and therapeutic method for intussusception, so it would be the next step in management. Abdominal CT scan and radiograph may help in diagnosis but are not the preferred methods. Observing for 24 hours would delay treatment and could potentially worsen the condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest intussusception, a condition in which part of the intestine folds into itself, causing obstruction and pain. Air enema is a diagnostic and therapeutic procedure used to correct intussusception in children. All other options are either not useful in diagnosing intussusception or do not provide a definitive treatment.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest intussusception, which is a medical emergency. An air enema should be performed to confirm the diagnosis and treat the condition. Abdominal CT scan and radiograph are not the first-line diagnostic tools for intussusception. Observing for 24 hours is not recommended as this can delay treatment and lead to complications.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of intermittent and severe stomach pain, vomiting, mucousy and bloody stools suggest intussusception, which is the telescoping of one part of the small intestine into another. The air enema is a diagnostic and therapeutic procedure that is used to reduce the intussusception in most cases. A CT scan or radiograph may be used to confirm the diagnosis but the air enema should be attempted first. Observation for 24 hours is not recommended as intussusception can lead to bowel obstruction and ischemia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described suggest intussusception, which is a medical emergency. Air enema is the recommended first-line treatment to diagnose and treat intussusception. Abdominal CT scan or radiograph may be used in some cases, but should not delay urgent management. Observing for 24 hours may lead to worsening of symptoms and delay treatment.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including severe stomach ache, vomiting, mucousy and bloody stools, suggest the presence of intussusception, which is a medical emergency that requires immediate treatment. An air enema is the diagnostic and therapeutic intervention of choice and is recommended as the next step in management.
